title: Release software regularly [TO BE DELETED]

details.body:
You must release software regularly.

The way you design and build applications is affected by how often you release updates to your service’s software.

[HOW?]

As early as possible in your product’s development, think about how you release updates to a running application.

[CAN WE MAKE THIS MORE CLEAR? LIKE EXACTLY WHAT SHOULD I BE THINKING ABOUT AS REGARDS HOW I RELEASE UPDATES? HOW OFTEN?]

This is because it affects how software is developed and tested, and how your service may be supported.

[CAN WE EXPLAIN THIS PARAGRAPH AND WHAT IT MEANS FOR THE READER/USER? WHEN I THINK ABOUT HOW I RELEASE UPDATES, WHAT CONCLUSIONS COULD I COME TO?

AND THEN HOW SHOULD THESE AFFECT HOW I DEVELOP AND TEST SOFTWARE OR SUPPORT MY SERVICE?]

Why you must release regularly

You must build a service you can continuously improve, to meet the following points in the [Digital Service Standard]:

  • [point 4 - use agile methods]
  • [point 5 - iterate and improve frequently]
  • [point 6 - evaluate tools and systems]

You’ll have to explain how you’re meeting these points, at your [service assessment].

Advantages of releasing regularly

You should release regularly for the following reasons:

  • your users get to benefit from new features or improvements quickly, instead of waiting until whenever your next fixed update is
  • your team is in the habit of releasing and doesn’t have to do one major release with many features launching at the same time
  • smaller and more frequent releases mean fewer things changing at the same time - this makes it easier to find the reason for any problem
  • it allows you to make the case for buying automation tools - these remove the chance of human error and make each release the same
  • it allows you to stage quick experiments to improve your service

Getting ready for regular releases

Your application should always be in a state where you can release - this allows you to make quick changes.

To make sure you can always release, you need to consider:

  • your approach to testing [WHAT DO I NEED TO CONSIDER ABOUT MY APPROACH TO TESTING?]
  • the quality of low-level code – approaches like test-driven design and continuous integration (where code is tested constantly) can help [WHAT SHOULD I CONSIDER ABOUT THE QUALITY OF MY CODE?]
  • using the same tools and release processes for both the development and production environments - this way your team will be very familiar with them before launch

Focus on your service

When you’re deciding how to make rapid releases possible, start by considering what your service and product team need. [SHOULD WE SAY USERS HERE TOO?]

You may need tools (including commercial tools) to help, but don’t make this the focus of your first discussions.

Measure how you deal with problems

You should measure the amount of time it takes you to fix problems.

[HOW DO I ACTUALLY MEASURE THIS? COULD WE EXPLAIN HERE OR IS IT IN ANOTHER PART OF THE MANUAL?]

Problems will always happen at some point, so it’s best to focus on how you deal with them, rather than expecting to eliminate them entirely.
